Award.AwardTitle: Microfluidic Printing of Interspersed and Interpenetrating Multicomponent Ceramic Architectures
Award.AbstractNarration:
NON-TECHNICAL DESCRIPTION: Three-dimensional (3D) printing offers the potential to digitally specify the form and function of materials. This project focuses on patterning 3D ceramic architectures by designing and implementing microfluidic printheads for use with model colloidal suspensions - i.e. concentrated fluids, gels, and biphasic mixtures - whose flow behavior can be directly imaged within microfluidic core-shell and multinozzle printheads. Advances from this research effort are expediting the transformation of 3D printing from rapid prototyping to a true manufacturing platform. The fundamental knowledge gained from this program of research will enable low-cost, high-throughput printing of designer ceramics that may find application as 3D ceramic composites, membranes, and battery electrodes. In addition, new scientific understanding of the flow and mixing of concentrated colloidal suspensions within confined microfluidic geometries is emerging from this effort.

TECHNICAL DETAILS: This project focuses on 3D printing of concentrated colloidal inks in interspersed and interpenetrating motifs using microfluidic core-shell and multinozzle printheads. Fundamental relationships between ink rheology, printhead designs, and printing behavior are being systematically investigated. The resulting 3D ceramic architectures may offer significant performance advantages in a broad range of applications, including lightweight composites, membranes, and batteries. The project integrates multiple education and outreach activities aimed at expanding the number of underrepresented groups in science, technology, engineering and mathematics (STEM) through public lectures and hands-on activities as well as by creating scientific videos of our research targeted for the DIY (do-it-yourself) and maker communities.

Institution.Name: Harvard University
Institution.ORG_LGL_BUS_NAME: PRESIDENT AND FELLOWS OF HARVARD COLLEGE

POR.DRECONTENT:
Three-dimensional (3D) printing enables the rapid design and fabrication of advanced materials. Our project focused on establishing the fundamental knowledge needed to create 3D ceramic architectures with controlled porosity across multiple length scales. To construct these porous ceramics, we produced particle-stabilized foams that consisted of air bubbles coated with ceramic particles and suspended in water. The particles prevent the bubbles within the foam from collapsing or interacting with one another.  The bubble size and total content can be tuned by altering the ceramic particle content, surface chemistry and foaming conditions. We further optimized their composition to ensure that these foam-based inks were well suited for 3D printing. Finally, we printed the foam-based inks into lightweight cellular architectures, including both honeycombs and 3D lattices, and characterized their strength and stiffness. These engineered porous ceramics are of significant interest for applications ranging from catalyst supports and filters to electrodes for batteries and supercapacitors. 

Additive manufacturing techniques are revolutionizing how materials are produced worldwide. Hence, a complementary outcome of this project is the education and training of the next generation of materials scientists with expertise in the additive manufacturing of ceramics.  Our research opens new avenues for producing advanced ceramics via digital manufacturing. 


Last Modified: 07/05/2018
Modified by: Jennifer A Lewis

    Joseph Muth, James Weaver, and Jennifer Lewis

These engineered porous ceramics are of significant interest for applications ranging from catalyst supports and filters to electrodes for batteries and supercapacitors. Additive manufacturing techniques are revolutionizing how materials are produced worldwide. Hence, a complementary outcome of this project is the education and training of the next generation of materials scientists with expertise in the additive manufacturing of ceramics. Our research opens new avenues for producing advanced ceramics via digital manufacturing. Last Modified: 07/05/2018 Submitted by: Jennifer A Lewis
